hedline.hl1: Tenant Groups Say End to Rent Caps Would Be a 'Disaster'

abstract.p: Assessment of new television commercial on rent control that was produced by tenant advocacy groups; photo (M)

block.p: Three tenant advocacy groups have produced a 30-second commercial on rent regulations that will begin appearing on local stations today.
Three tenant advocacy groups have produced a 30-second commercial on rent regulations that will begin appearing on local stations today.

ON THE SCREEN -- The advertisements begin with ominous music and an image of a book emblazoned with the title ''The Pataki-D'Amato Vacancy Decontrol Plan.'' As the announcer's words flash on the screen, a blurry picture of Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato appears beside the book. The commercial ends with the office phone numbers of Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato.

THE TEXT -- ''The Pataki-D'Amato plan for vacancy decontrol means an end to rent protection, and it's a disaster for 2.7 million New York tenants. The Republicans tried vacancy decontrol once before. The result? Increased evictions. Tenant harassment. And rents that shot up more than 50 percent. Now the Pataki-D'Amato team wants to use vacancy decontrol to take away rent protection again. Don't let them. Tell Pataki and D'Amato vacancy decontrol is the wrong answer.''

ACCURACY -- The vacancy decontrol plan presented by Mr. Pataki would bring an end to the rent regulation system, but slowly. From 1971 to 1974, New York experimented with vacancy decontrol, but the effects are still in dispute. Studies did not examine the number of evictions, but reports found that rents increased an average of 40 to 52 percent.

SCORECARD -- While Governor Pataki has tried to present vacancy decontrol as a moderate approach, the ad effectively points out that it will end rent regulations and that could lead to higher rents in only a few years. By linking Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato to plans to end rent rules, the ad calls into question claims by both that they are trying to protect tenants.
